column6: Nature and total number of critical concerns

column13: Subject to the Board's approval each year, $1,000 worth of Vicinity securities are granted annually to eligible employees for nil consideration. Securities granted are subject to a three-year trading restriction unless the employee ceases to be employed by the Group. Participants in the LTI do not participate in the TERSO.
column20: Remuneration Policies, Employee Benefits, Long-Term Incentives

column13: The STI allows eligible employees to receive an annual, performance-based incentive award when a combination of short-term Group financial, strategy and portfolio enhancement, and individual performance objectives are achieved. For executive KMP, other members of the ELT and other senior executives, a portion of the annual STI award is deferred into equity for 12 to 24 months.
column20: Short-Term Incentives, Performance Evaluation, Employee Benefits

column13: Executive KMP, other members of the Executive Leadership Team (ELT) and other senior executives are granted a combination of performance and restricted rights to acquire Vicinity securities for nil consideration. Performance rights granted are subject to Total Shareholder Return (TSR) and Total Return (TR) hurdles.
column20: Executive Compensation, Equity Compensation, Performance Evaluation

column7: Vicinity has a Remuneration and Human Resources Committee, which assists the Board in fulfilling its corporate governance responsibilities about the remuneration framework, remuneration and performance of the CEO, and the ELT and remuneration disclosures.

column7: Consumers and local communities, Suppliers and contractors, Retailers, Strategic partners, Securityholders, Our people, Government and regulators, Industry groups, Community groups

Vicinity respects and is guided by Fair Work Australia and the Fair Work Act 2009 on individuals' rights to join freely and form a trade union of their choice and their right to collective bargaining.
Our significant stakeholders are outlined below (which have been identified through our ongoing relationships with these groups across our operations)

We also continue to engage with Local, State and Federal Government agencies, non-governmental organisations, Aboriginal Land Councils, community groups and our retailers. These collaborations are essential to our commitment to greater transparency and driving collective action on sustainability.

column13: We recognise that leveraging the skills and diversity of our people to foster a high-performing, inclusive and safe culture is critical for our sustained success. Over the past 12 months, we continued to build on our inclusive culture by listening to our teams and implementing actions based on what they have told us. Driving this cultural focus will help create an environment for our people where they can thrive in an evolving customer landscape and create rewarding growth opportunities through bespoke learning and development programs, enabling them to succeed professionally and personally.
column20: Diversity and Inclusion, Employee Well-being, Organizational Culture

column6: Entities included in the consolidated financial statements
column7: Vicinity's directly owned portfolio (Direct Portfolio) comprising interests in 59 shopping centres is valued at $14.4 billion, just over half of which comprises Vicinity's Premium portfolio, which includes Chadstone, Australia's pre-eminent retail and mixed-use destination, seven CBD centres located across Australia's three largest cities, and Australia's leading Outlet Centre portfolio.

column6: Defining report content and topic Boundaries
column7: The report discloses our performance and management of sustainability issues material to our business and key stakeholders.
Climate risk, environmental sustainability, social capital, human capital, pandemic impact, leadership and governance, data ethics

Where relevant, prior period figures have been restated when more accurate data becomes available or when there have been material changes to the data calculation and estimation methodologies. Historical data in our FY23 Sustainability Performance Pack has been restated to reflect asset ownership as of 30 June 2023 and includes assets divested in FY23.
All performance data in this report is based on the 12-months
ended 30 June 2023 (FY23), or as of 30 June 2023, unless otherwise stated.

column6: Explanation of the material topic and its Boundary
column7: Vicinity's identified material issues were considered through an extensive peer review and stakeholder engagement. Where possible, critical United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)1 were provided for material topics to align our efforts to contribute to global sustainable development. Leveraging these SDGs allows us to demonstrate our awareness of economic, environmental and social impacts and frame the communication of our sustainability journey.

column6: The management approach and its components
column13: We have committed to reducing our environmental footprint and contributing positively to our communities. Our approach addresses climate change's cause and impact with three key objectives: Deliver our Net Zero Target, Increase total renewable energy usage, and Strengthen agility and capacity to adapt to climate-related risks.
column20: Environmental Sustainability, Climate Action, Community Engagement

column13: We use recognised national frameworks such as the Green Star and NABERS rating tools to benchmark our developments and operational performance. These frameworks help us to drive continuous improvement and more robust sustainability performance across our portfolio. As a result, we aim to deliver positive outcomes for our consumers, retail partners, suppliers, and people.
column20: Sustainable Development, Performance Metrics, Stakeholder Engagement

column13: Our centre teams are passionate about driving sustainable operational performance across our portfolio, focusing on continually improving, or best practice, initiatives. As a result, we have been able to deliver year-on-year improvements in the operational performance of our assets as we remain on track to achieve our Net Zero Target.
column20: Operational Efficiency, Sustainability Initiatives, Stakeholder Engagement

column7: We analysed the topics identified in the sustainability landscape review and the stakeholder engagement sessions. Each topic was assessed based on the level of stakeholder concern or interest, level of risk or scale of opportunity and our impact on the environment, economy and society about each topic. A validation workshop was held with ELT and the Sustainability team members to confirm the material ESG topics and their priority.

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: The Green Bond was used to refinance our lower carbon buildings (with NABERS Energy ratings of 5 stars or above) while diversifying our debt funding sources and extending our tenor. The Bond also enabled Vicinity to help address the increasing desire from debt investors looking to invest in sustainable debt products.
column20: Sustainable Finance, Green Investments, Carbon Reduction

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: Our centres nationwide are passionate about making a difference within their local communities. Our community investment program, which includes youth engagement opportunities and supporting other community initiatives in the centre, is focused on our role in building more robust and more resilient communities and safe, inclusive and accessible spaces within our precincts.
column20: Community Engagement, Social Responsibility, Local Impact

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: Develop a circular economy strategy to build on our commitment to increasing waste diversion from landfills and incorporate circular design principles in new developments.
column20: Circular Economy, Waste Management, Sustainable Practices

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: To mitigate the impacts of climate change, we are committed to decarbonising our operations and developments. Our Net Zero Target, established in 2019, is being delivered through our large-scale onsite solar program, scaled-up energy efficiency initiatives, demand management and a transition away from carbon-intensive energy sources through scaling back fossil fuel-reliant equipment.
column20: Climate Mitigation, Renewable Energy, Sustainable Development
